fields.definition: Refers to a person or group holding an unquestioned belief, argument, or philosophy without critical examination.
fields.clue: Blind obedience.  Following orders from above with neither question nor thought.

fields.definition: A type of organization that operates in opposite fashion to a bureaucracy.
fields.clue: Where once there was bureaucracy, here lies the solution to endless red tape.

fields.definition: electronic messages from a company's executives that are of little value to the employee who has received it
fields.clue: Yet another inbox clogging email that no one reads but is afraid to delete as it may be important later on.  Number one cause of 'inbox over the limit' messages.

fields.definition: the sharing of information between two (or more) people
fields.clue: The trendy way of sharing information. Circa 2013.

fields.definition: the levels of management where big, impractical, and counterproductive decisions are made
fields.clue: That particular level of management who spend so long working out the answer, no one can even remember the question.

fields.definition: Someone who makes lots of noise, disrupts everything, has the potential to make a big mess - but ultimately does nothing.
fields.clue: You all know the guy.  So much talk, so little action.

fields.definition: someone who utilizes gifts and flattery as means of attempting to achieve promotion or favor.
fields.clue: "Ohh, your hair is looking fabulous today.  Did you get it cut?  Now about that promotion..."

fields.definition: All talk, no action. Four-letter acronym describing a person who makes promises with great fanfare, but seldom follows through
fields.clue: All talk, no action.  The quickest way to describe the guy who promises the world, then delivers nothing.

fields.definition: Solving a difficult problem by pulling staff and resources from the four corners of the company to develop a solution.
fields.clue: Solving a difficult problem by pulling staff and resources out of the woodwork to develop a solution.

fields.definition: Old style managers that see things as right or wrong, leaving no room for discussion
fields.clue: The kind of boss who sees it as black or white, with nothing inbetween.

fields.definition: To deflect responsibility by pointing the finer at someone else.
fields.clue: Seek our the weakest and most vulnerable employee and place the blame at their feet.  After all, it's your mortage/ income/ life at stake.

fields.definition: A group process where participants analyze a failed project and look for scapegoats other than themselves
fields.clue: The group process of blaming everyone and everything.  Apart from yourself.

fields.definition: The mass nod of agreement by participants in a meeting to comments made by the boss even though most have no idea what he just said
fields.clue: A boardroom full of nodding colleagues, daydreaming about what to have for lunch, who don't have a clue what's being said.

fields.definition: An acronym muttered by the people who do the real work when senior managers announce their latest and greatest sales/customer service/quality initiative
fields.clue: Often heard being muttered by the people who do the real work, when senior management announce the latest round of performance/sales/customer initiatives.

fields.definition: To undertake an impossible task or project or to make a task or project unnecessarily difficult.
fields.clue: Making the impossible, impossible.

fields.definition: Quick-fix solutions or business practices that turn toxic
fields.clue: Quick-fix solutions or business practices that turn toxic

fields.definition: A meeting scheduled during lunch house in which the employee not only has to work but must bring his or her own lunch
fields.clue: Not only a meeting scheduled during your lunch hour, but one in which you must bring your own lunch.

fields.definition: Bring Your Own Advil. Description for a task that's sure to give you a headache.
fields.clue: Bring Your Own Advil.  For this project, you're going to need it...

fields.definition: The process of a company repeatedly reducing head count, but not the work, until it goes under.
fields.clue: Repeatedly reducing head count, but not the work, until the business eventually goes under.

fields.definition: A seasoned, outside salesperson, who has traveled extensively, been responsible for meeting a large quota and has the ulcers to prove it.
fields.clue: A hardcore salesman who has more than earned his airmiles.

fields.definition: CEO-speak for replacing a fellow chief executive
fields.clue: Swapping one big cheese for another.

fields.definition: The act of Ccing an e-mail message to anyone even remotely involved in a decision or action in order to cover your own butt.
fields.clue: The act of copying the whole world and his dog into an email to cover your own butt.

fields.definition: A term used to describe what a company does just before it goes down the tubes.
fields.clue: Last ditch attempt at swimming, even when you know you're aboard a sinking ship.

fields.definition: Successful women in powerful positions having it all.
fields.clue: The business equivalent of Carrie Bradshaw. You name it, she's got it.

fields.definition: A blend of acquired and hired.
fields.clue: Can't find the staff these days?  Not to worry. Just buy out the whole team.

fields.definition: Someone who uses minimal energy to get the task accomplished.
fields.clue: The absolute bare minimum required to get the job done.

fields.definition: Doing three things at once.
fields.clue: Multi-tasking three things at once.

fields.definition: Description of someone whose sole motivation is money.
fields.clue: Only springs into life when money's involved.

fields.definition: The degree of dullness of a meeting, presentation or reading material
fields.clue: Degree of dullness. Applies to meetings, presentations, literature - potentially some colleagues...

fields.definition: An opinion or position no one really loves, but everyone is able to live with.
fields.clue: The position that noone really loves, but everyone can live with.

fields.definition: An organization's strategic plan that's displayed prominently behind an executive's desk, but sits untouched until it's updated the following year.
fields.clue: A company strategy that's prepared lovingly, displayed proudly on the walls - then never touched again. Until of course it's updated, the following year. See also 'Wallpaper'.

fields.definition: "rest, relax and mentally recharge"
fields.clue: Stop working, chill, recharge your brain.

fields.definition: To be reviled or boycotted for voicing an unpopular political sentiment.
fields.clue: Boycotted and reviled because of the (office) political sentiments you've voiced.

fields.definition: The coded language spoken by diplomats to "send a message"   without actually committing to anything
fields.clue: Abbreviation of Diplomat-Speak: the langauge that can be spoken, without saying anything at all.

fields.definition: Consultant-speak for “Trust us. We don’t have a specific answer, but if you go in this general direction we think you’ll be making the right decision.”
fields.clue: Pointing people in the right direction - without giving them any actual directions. Often said in consultancy.

fields.definition: A receptionist. Once the punch line of an Internet joke, it's now an actual job title at some companies.
fields.clue: Receptionist. Once the the punchline of a joke - now an actual job title! Who's laughing now? We're not sure, either.

fields.definition: To remove ambiguities. To make clear. Used extensively by software developers
fields.clue: Make clear.

fields.definition: An employee that is learning something the hard way, like being immersed in their field of employment.
fields.clue: Being thrown in at the deep end, and learning a lot - at risk of getting burnt, along the way.

fields.definition: A difficult situation that a company or individual experiences that will result in either success or failure.
fields.clue: A hard, make-or-break situation for a company or individual.

fields.definition: The core teachings, skills and research in a field or industry.
fields.clue: This fundamentals of an industry, right down to the basics.

fields.definition: An employee with low ambition and, consequently, low productivity.
fields.clue: Someone whose low ambition makes for low productivity.

fields.definition: An investment strategy in which investors mimic the trades of well-known and historically successful investors.
fields.clue: Copycat investment strategy, mimicing the actions of successful investors.

fields.definition: The solicitation of potential customers who were not anticipating such an interaction.
fields.clue: Calling a potential customer or client who isn't expecting to hear from you. Expect a cold response!

fields.definition: The act of making a process, good or service easy to obtain by making it as uniform, plentiful and affordable as possible.
fields.clue: To make a process, product or service available to everyone; by making it unfiform, plentiful and cheap.

fields.definition: A person on a company's board of directors who votes and acts on the wishes of a non-board member.
fields.clue: A board memember who acts on the wishes of someone outside of the top team - like a total dummy.

fields.definition: A brief speech that outlines an idea for a product, service or project.
fields.clue: Brief speech outlining a product, service or idea - the way you would if you had just 60 seconds. In, say, an elevator...

fields.definition: The act of attempting to increase the size and scope of an individual or organization's power and influence.
fields.clue: Trying to widen the scope of power and influence - of either an individual, or a company.

fields.definition: Someone who is high up in a company due to unfair hiring practices, such as nepotism, and doesn't really do anything for the company.
fields.clue: Wishful term for the guy who does nothing much - but gets high up in the company, through unfair hiring.

fields.definition: A baseball reference applied to businesses that train employees only to have them leave for competing firms.
fields.clue: A business that trains great employees - before they leave and join competing firms. Originally a baseball term.

fields.definition: A word used to describe executives who earn what many believe to be unreasonably high salaries and bonuses.
fields.clue: The executive with a ridiculously high salary or bonus - who generally gets more of the cream than they should.

fields.definition: Term used to describe the practice of a labor union requiring an employer to hire more workers than necessary for a particular task.
fields.clue: Hiring someone unnecessarily - whose role it is to hire people unnecessairly - for one overstaffed project.

fields.definition: A collection of financial incentives that are intended to encourage employees to remain with a company.
fields.clue: A set of financial perks intended to retain employees.

fields.definition: A signing bonus offered to a candidate from a rival company.
fields.clue: Reserved for a job candidate from a rival company, this is a special way of saying 'hi': with a huge signing bonus.

fields.definition: An exceptional compensation package offered by the acquiring company to the top executives of the company being bought.
fields.clue: Handier than it sounds: a financial package offered by an acquiring company, to the top team of the company they acquire.

fields.definition: Using a product yourself which you sell to others
fields.clue: Using the product you're selling to others.

fields.definition: A company's ability to retain a piece of the publics consciousness
fields.clue: Amount of space your company takes up in the public's thoughts - like cerebral real estate!

fields.definition: The raw number of people that look at a website
fields.clue: People - when talking about the raw number of them that look at a website.

fields.definition: Any advertisement or marketing message that is presented to users as useful information.
fields.clue: An advert, fused with (or disguised as) useful information.

fields.definition: A term used by market researchers for the "coolest kid in the neighborhood."
fields.clue: 'Coolest kid in town': rare species sought widely by market researchers.

fields.definition: non-scientific observations or studies, which do not provide proof but may assist research efforts
fields.clue: Non-scientific observations and stories, used to back up an argument.

fields.definition: Any action or practice that would reflect badly on the company
fields.clue: Actions that aren't pretty, when it comes to their effect on company reputation.

fields.definition: Anything that has little or no substance
fields.clue: Anything with little or no substance.

fields.definition: A term used to describe customers who cost more to serve than they return in value
fields.clue: Customers who cost more to serve than they actually spend.

fields.definition: Branding schemes that strip out any uniqueness in a corporate identity in order to appear to a larger audience
fields.clue: Branding that takes away identity and uniqueness instead of adding to it - in an attempt to please a wider audience.

fields.definition: Anything that’s overwritten- often padded with unnecessary adjectives or laden with hyperbole. Also appropriately known as 'BS'
fields.clue: Overwritten, padded with unnecessary syllables, adjectives and rhetoric; better known simply as 'BS'.

fields.definition: Paying well-known bloggers to write about a product or service under the guise of newsworthy information.
fields.clue: Paying successful bloggers to write about a product or service.

fields.definition: Someone who relentlessly trumptes the brand and pushes for all decisions to be aligned with the company’s "brand essence"
fields.clue: The one who talks non-stop about the brand and wants everything aligned to company 'brand essence'. And we mean everything.

fields.definition: A company's value based on name recognition and brand, not tangible assets.
fields.clue: A company's value as measured by its brand, reputation and name recognition.

fields.definition: When a new marketing channel steals business from existing channels without adding new growth.
fields.clue: When a new marketing channel eats up all the business from existing ones - without adding new growth.

fields.definition: Marketing-speak for anything that focuses on the needs of the customer.
fields.clue: Revolving around the customer and their needs.

fields.definition: "Advertising is no longer about interrupting what people are interested in, it's about being what people are interested in."
fields.clue: Advertising by entertaining.

fields.definition: when an online store treats brick and mortar stores as their showroom.
fields.clue: When an online retailer uses physical stores as their showroom: knowing that customers will buy online after they've looked at the product in-store.

fields.definition: A Web page that opens after you unsubscribe from an e-mail list, where a final appeal is made to keep you.
fields.clue: The website that opens after you unsubscribe from a mailing list as a last desperate shot at persuading you to stay.

fields.definition: any anecdote or opinion disguised as fact that can be used to persuade others.
fields.clue: An opinion disguised as a cold hard fact that's used to make a point.

fields.definition: Anything that's not on the immediate horizon or is a low priority.
fields.clue: A project currently on the back burner.

fields.definition: Death by Tweakage. When a product or project fails due to unnecessary tinkering or too many last-minute revisions.
fields.clue: Death by Tweakage.  A project ruined by too many cooks spoiling the broth.

fields.definition: To tone down or take a step back
fields.clue: To take a step back.

fields.definition: A retail store that occupies an enormous amount of physical space and offers a variety of products to its customers.
fields.clue: AKA supercenter, superstore or super retail outlet offering absolutely everything to absolutely everyone.

fields.definition: A market theory that suggests that when a company reveals bad news to the public, there may be many more related negative events that have yet to be revealed.
fields.clue: The theory that behind every bit of bad news, there's much more to be revealed.  As a wise man once said, "There's never just one."

fields.definition: A market that is believed to have the potential to make a strong move in one direction after being pushed in the opposite direction.
fields.clue: A market that is believed to have the potential to make a strong move in one direction after being pushed in the opposite direction.

fields.definition: A project-management technique that lays out all the activities needed to complete a task, the time it will take to complete each activity and the relationships between the activities.
fields.clue: A fancy project management term for working out where we need to get to, and how we're going to get there.

fields.definition: A product or service that has an energetic and loyal customer base.
fields.clue: Most brands can but dream of reaching these lofty heights.

fields.definition: Trading that occurs outside of general market regulations.
fields.clue: Trading with little regard for the rules.

fields.definition: A failure that occurs as a result of many smaller problems.
fields.clue: A failure resulting from the combination of many smaller problems.

fields.definition: When property, stocks or other assets are sold in an urgent manner, often at a loss.
fields.clue: A rapid, urgent sale of assets, often at a loss.

fields.definition: Intense competition in a market.
fields.clue: Survival of the fittest.

fields.definition: A marketing and sales strategy retailers use to get a high volume of customers into their stores.
fields.clue: The practise of offering too-good-to-be-true prices to customers to get them through the door.

fields.definition: Selling goods or assets at heavily discounted prices.
fields.clue: Urgently selling goods at heavily discounted prices.

fields.definition: A product or service that is developed and distributed globally, but is also fashioned to accommodate the user or consumer in a local market.
fields.clue: Imagine a McDonald's Big Mac with the flavours of Mumbai.

fields.definition: A company that dominates an industry without having a complete monopoly.
fields.clue: A company that dominates an industry without having a complete monopoly.

fields.definition: The collective effort of individuals who network and pool their resources to support efforts initiated by other people or organizations.
fields.clue: The team effort by lots of individuals to support a person or company's initiative; by pooling thoughts and resources.

fields.definition: Financial instruments that have an impressive growth rate - but also a high risk factor
fields.clue: Financial instruments with a nice growth rate - and a nasty risk factor.

fields.definition: Big Damn Number
fields.clue: Big Damn Number!

fields.definition: Term used to describe the sense of inadequacy, shame and regret felt by an individual whenever the stock market takes a dip.
fields.clue: Sense of inadequacy, shame and regret felt when the stock market dips.

fields.definition: Money left over at the end of the budget year
fields.clue: Money left at the end of the budget year. That's one kind of dust everyone wants to clean up...

fields.definition: The "use it or lose it" spending spree that occurs near the end of the fourth quarter.
fields.clue: 'Use it or lose it' spending frenzy at the end of the fourth quarter.

fields.definition: When the market is flat and not moving in either direction. Investors are indecisive - like deer frozen in the headlights.
fields.clue: A market that's frozen in the headlights, not moving in either direction, and potentially about to get flattened.

fields.definition: A significant amount of money.
fields.clue: A significant sum of money. Say, a ton...

fields.definition: an acquisition or merger in which the companies involved have trouble integrating with one another.
fields.clue: Trouble two companies have with integrating, after an acquisition or merger.

fields.definition: A physical location in a brokerage where securities are kept.
fields.clue: Physical place where stocks, bonds and other securities are kept, in a brokerage.

fields.definition: A social condition arising from the desire to be more wealthy, successful or to "keep up with the Joneses".
fields.clue: Incurable desire to 'keep up with the Joneses' through more wealth and success.

fields.definition: A stock that experiences a sudden drop, usually the result of investors reacting to negative news.
fields.clue: A stock that drops suddenly in value, like a plane in an air pocket. Without the complimentary sick bags. Often caused by investors' reactions to bad news.

fields.definition: A trust agreement in which a divorced person agrees to pay spousal support from the income generated from a trust.
fields.clue: Agreement for a divorcee to pay their ex-partner support from a trust.

fields.definition: A stock with low market capitalization.
fields.clue: A stock with low market capitalization.

fields.definition: A postulated antithesis to fragility where high-impact events or shocks can be beneficial.
fields.clue: The theory that high-impact events or shocks can be benefical. Opposes the theory of fragility, which connects these events to financial downfall.

fields.definition: A market theory that states stock prices and aspirin production are inversely related.
fields.clue: The theory that when stock prices go up, aspirin production goes down. A headache to understand...

fields.definition: Capital required to be set aside in order to cover a company against unexpected debt.
fields.clue: Money set aside to secure a company against debts that could surprise them in future.

fields.definition: The sale of an asset or item at a price significantly above the original purchase price due to high demand, rather than appreciation.
fields.clue: At a sale price that's much higher than what the vendor paid originally for the item - due to high demand, not actial appreciation in value.

fields.definition: An uneducated or unsophisticated investor.
fields.clue: An uneducated or unsophisticated investor.

fields.definition: When the bid on a limit order is lower than the current market price or the offer price is higher than the current market price, for a particular security.
fields.clue: On a limit order, a bid that's significantly lower or higher than the current market price.

fields.definition: The movement in spread, price or yield of a security, which makes it more expensive to issue.
fields.clue: A change in the spread, price or yield of a security - making it cost more to issue.

fields.definition: The purchase of a large position in a stock or other financial asset by an investor or trader
fields.clue: The buying of a large position in a stock or other asset, by an investor or trader. Vrrooom!

fields.definition: The negative effect felt by a company when shareholders and the investment community find out that is has done something that is not in accordance with good business practices.
fields.clue: What happens when you misbehave. The negative effect felt by a company when its investment community find out about its poor business practices.

fields.definition: An investor who holds a position in a stock which decreases in value until it is worthless.
fields.clue: The investor who's positioned in a stock that keeps decreasing in value - until it's worth nothing.

fields.definition: A stock or other security that is approaching $0 in price.
fields.clue: A stock or other security so stale it's approaching a big, round $0 in price.

fields.definition: A compilation of market and economic data that represents a general or larger trend.
fields.clue: The market and economic data that indicates trends.

fields.definition: A period in which prices of stocks increase during a bear market.
fields.clue: A period over which stock prices increase, in spite of the self-fulfilling negativity of a bear market.

fields.definition: A change in market conditions that forces pessimistic investors attempting to profit from price declines to buy back an investment at a higher price than they sold it for.
fields.clue: The change in market conditions that squeezes money out of pessimistic investors; they try to profit from price declines, only to end up buying back their own assets at a higher price than at first.

fields.definition: A fall in the price of a stock, sector, or market, or investor sentiment that assumes a fall will happen soon.
fields.clue: Not as cute as it sounds. A fall in the price of a stock, market or sector - or a sentiment amongst investors that a fall is soon to come.

fields.definition: A stock that is believed to be a leading indicator of the direction of a sector, industry or market as a whole.
fields.clue: A stock that's held to be a weather forecast for the rest of its sector, industry or market - indicating its direction as a whole.

fields.definition: An investor who sells shares at or below the bid price.
fields.clue: Investor who sells shares at, or below, bid price.

fields.definition: A day of stock market catastrophe.
fields.clue: A day of stock market catastrophe, in which prices crash.

fields.definition: A company that makes a hostile takeover offer for a target company.
fields.clue: A company making a hostile takeover offer. Not to be confused with The Dark Knight.

fields.definition: An event or occurrence that deviates beyond what is normally expected of a situation and that would be extremely difficult to predict.
fields.clue: An unpredictable event; flying completely in the face of what you'd usually expect from a situation. They should have called it the bright purple swan...

fields.definition: A limited partnership or stock offering with no stated investment goal for the funds that are raised from investors.
fields.clue: Few people can see where they're going with this one; a limited partnership or stock offering with no official investment goal for the funds it raises.

fields.definition: A term used to describe a perfect stock or investment.
fields.clue: A perfect stock or investment - named bizarrely after a 70's film actress.

fields.definition: A benefit or improvement for investors.
fields.clue: Benefit or improvement for investors.

fields.definition: An investor who looks for bargains among stocks whose prices have recently dropped dramatically.
fields.clue: A bargain hunter, looking to invest in stocks whose prices have just fallen sharply.

fields.definition: A term used in futures markets to describe a rapid and sharp price decline.
fields.clue: Sharp, fast price decline - often in futures markets.

fields.definition: A type of stock initial public offering (IPO) that trades below the original offering price to the market within the first few months after trading begins.
fields.clue: A type of stock that, after a few months of being released to the public, starts to trade below its initial offering price.

fields.definition: When a security or a class of assets sees its market-driven price move in the opposite direction of the broad market or its competition.
fields.clue: To have a price that moves in the opposite direction to the market, or its competition. Said of securities, or certain classes of assets.

fields.definition: A period of time during which economic growth decreases rapidly.
fields.clue: A time over which economic growth decreases rapidly.

fields.definition: When investors give up any previous gains in stock price by selling equities in an effort to get out of the market and into less risky investments.
fields.clue: Escaping from a risky market by selling equities - causing you to lose any previous gains in stock price.

fields.definition: An exchange of credits between nations designed to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide.
fields.clue: An exchange between nations, designed to reduce CO2 emissions.

fields.definition: One of the four categories (quadrants) in the BCG growth-share matrix that represents the division within a company that has a large market share within a mature industry.
fields.clue: Division within a company that has a large market share in a mature industry. A share eveyone can milk for years to come...

fields.definition: The belief that money (cash) is more valuable than any other form of investment tool.
fields.clue: The belief that money is more valuable than any other form of investment.

fields.definition: A term for an investment strategy that is considered extremely risky.
fields.clue: Risky investment strategy.

fields.definition: Large companies that put less efficient and highly specialized merchants out of business.
fields.clue: Giant companies that put others in their category - often specialist merchants - out of business.

fields.definition: A slang term referring to speculative stocks that have short or suspicious histories for sales, earnings, dividends etc
fields.clue: Speculative stocks with short, suspicious histories. May bite, if provoked.

fields.definition: A Latin phrase for "let the buyer beware."
fields.clue: Latin for "let the buyer beware".

fields.definition: A champagne stock is one that has made shareholders a great deal of money.
fields.clue: A stock that's made its investors enough money for a fountain of cuvée de prestige.

fields.definition: What a company's management does when it decides to trim small, trivial costs instead of cutting larger, more serious costs.
fields.clue: Cutting small, trivial costs; instead of bigger, serious ones.

fields.definition: The act of investors choosing investments that have performed well within another portfolio in anticipation that the trend will continue.
fields.clue: Choosing investments that have performed well in other sectors - in the hope that they'll do the same in yours. Tasty.

fields.definition: The ethical barrier between different divisions of a financial (or other) institution to avoid conflict of interest.
fields.clue: Information barrier that keeps investors' actions secret from others in their company, to avoid conflict of interest.

fields.definition: A debt investment that is said to have no principal, no interest and no maturity value.
fields.clue: A debt investment named after the onetime President that is said to have no principal, no interest and no maturity value...

fields.definition: A theory that seeks to explain the effect that 24-hour news networks, such as CNN, have on the general political and economic climate.
fields.clue: The general, political and economic effects experienced when 24 hour news networks cover a story.

fields.definition: Equity shares owned by major shareholders of a publicly traded corporation.
fields.clue: Equity shares owned by major sharedholders of a publicly traded corporation.

fields.definition: An accounting practice in which a company uses generous reserves from good years against losses that might be incurred in bad years.
fields.clue: Not as tasty as it sounds, this accounting practice sees companies using generous reserves from better days against losses incurred in bad years.

fields.definition: A term used to describe someone considered to have bad luck with stock picking.
fields.clue: Someone who really shouldn't be selected to do the stock picking.

fields.definition: The performance of a publicly traded company in non-financial areas such as social responsibility, sustainability and environmental performance.
fields.clue: How a company performs in relation to making the world a nicer place to be.

fields.definition: An act of self-infringement upon market share by corporations through the issuance of new products.
fields.clue: A company launching products into a market they already dominate and effectively.. competing against themselves!

fields.definition: Corporate initiative to assess and take responsibility for the company's effects on the environment and impact on social welfare.
fields.clue: The measures a company takes to have a positive impact on the world.

fields.definition: A ranking of countries according to the extent to which corruption is believed to exist.
fields.clue: A ranking of countries by level of corruption believed to exist.

fields.definition: A situation in which a creditor is forced to accept undesirable terms imposed by a court during a bankruptcy or reorganization.
fields.clue: A situation in which a creditor is forced to accept undesirable terms in the face of bankruptcy.

fields.definition: A sudden and significant decline in the value of a market.
fields.clue: A dramatic decline in the value of a market.

fields.definition: A crisis that occurs when several financial institutions issue or are sold high-risk loans that start to default.
fields.clue: A financial crisis that occurs when institutions are sold high-risk loans that default.

fields.definition: An economic condition in which investment capital is difficult to obtain.
fields.clue: The economic climate in which consumers panic and begin buying supermarket own labels 'coz it's the credit crunch, innit'.

fields.definition: A very important or crucial stage in a company's development, where the business activity acquires self-sustaining viability.
fields.clue: A really important stage in a company's development when it finally becomes able to support itself.

fields.definition: The most valuable unit(s) of a corporation, as defined by characteristics such as profitability, asset value and future prospects.
fields.clue: The most valuable part of an organisation.

fields.definition: A classification describing stocks that have a sizable investor following, despite the fact that the underlying company has somewhat insignificant fundamentals.
fields.clue: Stocks with a sizeable investor following in spite of the underlying company being somewhat insignificant.

fields.definition: The "real time" price of a security trading on an exchange, as well as the most recent price of a security listed in an investment portfolio.
fields.clue: The 'real time' price of stock.

fields.definition: A term used to describe when a board of directors declares an additional dividend in addition to the regular distribution.
fields.clue: When a board of directors declares an additional dividend in addition to the regular distribution.

fields.definition: A stipulation on a defense mechanism (or poison pill) used by companies in order to protect against a merger or takeover by another company.
fields.clue: A poison pill used by companies to protect against a merger or takeover by another company.

fields.definition: The condition of a company, whether publicly traded or private, that has gone bankrupt and ceased to exist.
fields.clue: When a company no longer exists.

fields.definition: A dishonest broker tactic that involves convincing a client to purchase a stock because it's about to pay a dividend.
fields.clue: Convincing a client to purchase stock because it's about to pay a dividend.

fields.definition: The process of adding investments to one's portfolio in such a way that the risk/return trade-off is worsened.
fields.clue: Adding investments to a portfolio in such a way that the risk/ return trade-off is worsened.

fields.definition: A term referring to a financial seminar that presents new products or issues of securities to potential buyers.
fields.clue: A financial seminar that presents new products or issues of securities to potential buyers.

fields.definition: An investing strategy that consists of buying the 10 DJIA stocks with the highest dividend yield at the beginning of the year.
fields.clue: An investment strategy involving buying the 10 DJIA stocks with the highest dividend yield at the beginning of the year.

fields.definition: The negative movement in the price of a security, sector or market.
fields.clue: The negative movement in the price of a security, sector or market.

fields.definition: The process of investing on an ongoing basis in a small but growing firm over a period of time.
fields.clue: Investing on an ongoing basis in a small but growing firm over a period of time.

fields.definition: A provision in a contract or agreement that stipulates a finite deadline which, if not met, will automatically trigger adverse consequences.
fields.clue: A term in a contract that states a finite deadline which, if not met, will automatically trigger dire consequences.

fields.definition: A business venture that ends up being a loss.
fields.clue: An unsuccessful business venture that makes a loss.

fields.definition: A term referring to marketable securities that are highly liquid and considered cash-like.
fields.clue: Marketable securities that are highly liquid and considered as cash.

fields.definition: An entity that holds shares in a public company on behalf of an individual or firm, the latter being the real or true owner of these shares.
fields.clue: Someone who holds shares in a public company on behalf of an individual who is the true owner of the shares.

fields.definition: An adage that, referring to the risk/return trade-off, says that the type of security an investor chooses depends on whether he or she wants to eat well or sleep well.
fields.clue: A trader may not do much of this dependent on the risk/ return trade-off of his investments.

fields.definition: Large institutions that have the funds to make high volumes trades.
fields.clue: Large institutions with enough funds to make high volume trades.

fields.definition: A revolving credit arrangement in which the borrower periodically renews the debt financing rather than having the debt reach maturity.
fields.clue: A revolving credit arrangement in which a borrower renews debt financing periodically rather than allowing the debt to reach maturity.

fields.definition: Investing in companies or projects that promote fair trade with producers in developing nations.
fields.clue: Investing in companies or projects that make the world a better place to be.

fields.definition: A phrase for a security or industry in which the current price or value has dropped significantly in a short period of time.
fields.clue: When the current value of an industry drops significantly in a short period of time.

fields.definition: An additional letter added onto four-letter ticker symbols to signify to market participants that there is additional information about a specific company's stock.
fields.clue: An extra letter added onto a company's four letter ticker symbol to signify that there's additional information available.

fields.definition: The action of placing a trade or trades that go against the ticker tape.
fields.clue: Placing a trade against the ticker tape.

fields.definition: An accounting buzzword that describe when companies still have inventory on hand that is not being sold due to inattention or obsolescence.
fields.clue: When companies still have inventory that's not being sold.

fields.definition: The action of investors moving their capital away from riskier investments to the safest possible investment vehicles.
fields.clue: Investors moving risky investments to the safest investment vehicles as security.

fields.definition: A term indicating the last-minute infusion of cash into a company about to go bankrupt.
fields.clue: A last minute cash-injection into a company about to go bust.

fields.definition: A slang term for the Financial Times Actuaries 100 index (FTSE 100).
fields.clue: The Financial Times Actuaries 100 index.

fields.definition: A pattern of economic growth where periods of rapid expansion are followed by periods of slow growth.
fields.clue: A difficult to follow pattern of growth in which rapid expansion is followed by slow growth.

fields.definition: The unethical practice of a broker trading an equity based on information from the analyst department before his or her clients have been given the information.
fields.clue: The practice of a broker trading equity based on information provided by analysts before his clients have given permission.

fields.definition: An investor who attends the annual shareholders meeting to criticize the corporation's executives.
fields.clue: An investor who attends shareholder meetings to point out faults with the corporation's executives.

fields.definition: A high-growth company that is increasing its revenues by at least 20% annually for four years or more, starting from a revenue base of at least $1 million.
fields.clue: A high-growth company.

fields.definition: The practice of raising the price of a previously agreed-upon real estate transaction.
fields.clue: A cheeky practice originating from dodgy car salesmen who raised the price after a transaction had already been agreed.

fields.definition: An illegal practice whereby two or more market makers collectively attempt to influence and change the price of a stock.
fields.clue: A strictly illegal practice where two market makers join forces to influence and change the price of stock.

fields.definition: An irrefutable takeover offer made to a target company by an acquiring company.
fields.clue: "I'm gonna make him an offer he just can't refuse."

fields.definition: A source of lots of money, such as shoppers who are expected to spend a lot or high-income earners who are expected to pay a lot in taxes.
fields.clue: Close cousin of the cash cow, these shoppers sure know how to spend, spend and spend.

fields.definition: A type of share that gives its shareholder veto power over changes to the company's charter.
fields.clue: A type of share with special privileges - shareholders veto power over changes to the company's charter.

fields.definition: An economy that is not so hot that it causes inflation, and not so cold that it causes a recession.
fields.clue: A well balanced economy - not hot enough to cause inflation but not cold enough to cause a recession.

fields.definition: A term used to describe signs of economic recovery or positive data during an economic downturn.
fields.clue: Very good news - signs of economic recovery during an economic downturn.

fields.definition: content that provides a game-like experience, usually through an entertainment and reward system.
fields.clue: Turning content into a game-like experience, through entertainment and rewards.

fields.definition: anything about a website or content that encourages a visitor to linger longer.
fields.clue: Anything that encourages website visitors to stay a little bit longer.

fields.definition: When a technology is overtaken in the market by inferior but better marketed competition.
fields.clue: When an inferior technical product is better marketed and blasts the competition out of the water.

fields.definition: Software that has more features, buttons and capability than you'll ever need.
fields.clue: Software that has more features, buttons and shiny things than you'll ever need.

fields.definition: A mixture of a smartphone and tablet.
fields.clue: What happened after a tequila fuelled night of passion between a smartphone and a tablet...

fields.definition: A process used by companies to turn raw data into useful information.
fields.clue: The process that turns the rough diamond of raw data into shiny, useful information.

fields.definition: One yottabyte (abbreviated "YB") is equal to 1,000 zettabytes and is the largest SI unit of measurement used for measuring data.
fields.clue: Techie speak for a WHOLE lorry load of data.

fields.definition: a software bug that seems to disappear or alter its behavior when one attempts to study it.
fields.clue: More erratic than its quantum physics namesake, this shifty software bug seems to vanish or change when you try to study it.

fields.definition: removing redundant data from a system.
fields.clue: removing redundant data from a system.

fields.definition: web sites that use technology beyond the static pages of earlier web sites.
fields.clue: Static, vintage pages from the dark age of web tech: powered by newer technology beyond them.

fields.definition: means you’re too cheap to spend the money to buy a big enough computer system to handle all your business needs.
fields.clue: The tight wad who won't buy a computer system big enough to handle their business needs.

fields.definition: The trail of digital information you leave behind every time you use a credit card, send an e-mail, browse the Web or use a cell phone.
fields.clue: It's behind you... your own personal trail of digital information; left behind each time you use a credit card, make a cell phone call, browse the web or send an email.

fields.definition: To be overwhelmed with too much information (eg. A google search that turns up six million references)
fields.clue: Spring-cleaning redundant data out of a system.

fields.definition: The result of being so overwhelmed by the availability, speed and volume of digital information that you can’t remember any of it (or where you might have put it on your hard drive).
fields.clue: Being so overwhelmed with fast, plentiful data that you can't remember it - or where it is on your hard drive.

fields.definition: A type of business model, or segment of a larger business model, that enables a firm or individual to conduct business over an electronic network, typically the internet.
fields.clue: A type of business model, or segment of one, that lets a company do business over networks like the internet.

fields.definition: The sale of goods and services through the Internet.
fields.clue: Selling online.

fields.definition: Technology that is considered environmentally friendly based on its production process or supply chain.
fields.clue: Technology that's environmentally friendly from the word go - all the way through its supply chain and production process.

fields.definition: an essential shift from way one of thinking to another
fields.clue: Sadly not an office disco dance move - yet. This term describes a shift from one way of thinking to another.

fields.definition: businesses that have physical (rather than online or virtual) presences
fields.clue: Present physically in the business world, instead of online.

fields.definition: Technology that is acquired almost immediately after its release, regardless of the increased cost or risk involved
fields.clue: Technology acquired as soon as it's released - regardless of gory risks or cost increases for the buyers.

fields.definition: A traditional company that managed to successfully integrate the Internet into its existing channels.
fields.clue: A traditional company, with physical stores, that successfully incorporates Internet into its channels.

fields.definition: A role that replaces traditional marketing roles in fast-growing businesses.
fields.clue: A marketing role for trendy technie types.  Circa 2013.

fields.definition: Used for companies when they're 'changing direction' rather than indicating a mistake or something similarly negative.
fields.clue: A positive spin tech companies use to indicate 'changing direction'.  Not that they got it wrong.  Honest.

fields.definition: Corporate obesity. When companies become too big. "They become fat and complacent. They get lazy, lose their creativity and are no longer able to move quickly in the marketplace."
fields.clue: When companies eat all the pies, leaving them bloated, immobile and unable to act quickly against the competition.

fields.definition: The failure of a company or industry to accept that the Internet has changed the world and made their business model obsolete
fields.clue: Belligerent denial that the Internet has changed the world and refusal to adapt or accept change.

fields.definition: A fuel derived from organic oils, such as vegetable oil, rather than petroleum.
fields.clue: A fuel derived from organic oils, such as vegetable oil, rather than petroleum.

fields.definition: A company that embraces the internet as the key component in its business.
fields.clue: The 1990s movement that pioneered the digital revolution.

fields.definition: A form of competitive advantage that a company earns by being the first to enter a specific market or industry.
fields.clue: A company earns this competitive adventage by being the first to enter a specific market or industry.

fields.definition: A company that alters its business strategy and conceives an entirely new business plan.
fields.clue: A company that alters its business strategy and in doing so, conceives an entirely new business plan.

fields.definition: the use of emergent social software platforms within companies, or between companies and their partners or customers
fields.clue: The use of social media in business: both b2b, and b2c. We like it.

fields.definition: an idea, behavior, or style that spreads from person to person within a culture.
fields.clue: One idea, theme, behaviour or style that spreads from person to person; getting copied with lots of individual twists. Now, do the Harlem Shake...

fields.definition: short blog posts (twitter)
fields.clue: The art of teensy blog posts with a character limit - think Twitter.

fields.definition: An organized index page that collects a website’s posts from the past.
fields.clue: A neat index page that holds they key to a website's past - organising all of its historic posts, to browse through.

fields.definition: the descriptive words that describe a piece of media.
fields.clue: Words that best describe a piece of media - often used to identify it in an internet or database search.

fields.definition: an acronym for Really Simple Syndication. This XML based format has become the preferred standard for syndicating content across the web.
fields.clue: Rich Site Summary - later dubbed Really Simple Syndication - this style of web feed is the preferred way to send out lots of regular updates: blogs and news feeds, for example.

fields.definition: a diagram of the interconnections between people, with the people serving as nodes, and the lines between them showing the connections.
fields.clue: A diagram of the social connections between people: looks like what would happen if your social network was a giant, tangled constellation.

fields.definition: Generating publicity through social media to increase awareness of a product, brand or event
fields.clue: Making the most of Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Instagram to promote a brand or product.

fields.definition: the social universe created by online individuals using web log publishing platforms.
fields.clue: The online universe of self-publishing fanatics known as 'bloggers'.

fields.definition: A web-based tool that collects and delivers syndicated content.
fields.clue: Like a futuristic postman: an online tool that collects and delivers syndicated content.

fields.definition: Dynamic content is content that is constantly changing.
fields.clue: Content that's constantly evolving.

fields.definition: an audio program in a compressed digital format, which is deigned to be listened to over the web.
fields.clue: Audio program, compressed digitally to be heard or downloaded over the web.

fields.definition: a software distribution model in which applications are hosted by a vendor or service provider and made available to customers over a network.
fields.clue: When apps are hosted by a vendor, then made available to lots of customers over a network.

fields.definition: a paradigm for delivering operating systems and associated services over the Internet without downloads or installation
fields.clue: When platforms and operating systems are made available online - without the need for downloads and installing.

fields.definition: a cloud computing environment in which an organization provides and manages some resources in-house and has others provided externally.
fields.clue: In-house and external resources being fused in a company's cloud computing environment.

fields.definition: this is a marketing term for a proprietary computing architecture that provides hosted services to a limited number of people behind a firewall.
fields.clue: Marketing-speak for privately-hosted services, to a set number of people behind a firewall.

fields.definition: a term for using the Internet to store applications and data so it can be accessed remotely.
fields.clue: Omnipotent, omnipresent, and omniscient, it can't be seen yet it holds everything, everywhere.

fields.definition: a method of building interactive applications for the Web that process user requests immediately.
fields.clue: A method of building interactive apps that allows users to play with them immediately.

fields.definition: This is a software program that lets users map data from one application to another.
fields.clue: Tech speak for software that lets applications share data.

fields.definition: This term means that multiple companies are using a single, remotely hosted database.
fields.clue: Multiple companies sharing a single, remotely hosted database.

fields.definition: A public cloud is one based on the standard cloud computing model, in which a service provider makes resources, such as applications and storage, available to the general public over the Internet
fields.clue: Applications, storage and other resources made available to the public through the Internet.
